Each flu vaccine vaccinates against multiple strands of the flu.
We have had a few, Bird flu was pretty wide spread but over they are toned down by modern medicine and vaccination that can vaccinate against multiple diseases in one shot
4 but still 2 main ones

The details is there apparently 2 'main' branches of the flu. The first branch you come into contact with is the flu your body gears its response to; while the body does respond to the other branch, it uses the response that it would show to the first branch which is improper, rather it would be better if the body chalked up a new response to the scene branch.
Some generations predominantly encountered one branch while other generations encountered the other branch, leading to some flus being more deadly among different generations. In the case of the Spanish flu the older generation were exposed to the branch that the Spanish flu came from, while the younger generation was exposed to the other branch first in their life. This lead to the younger generation having a weaker and more inefficient defense versus the Spanish flu compared to the older generation.
Edit: link https://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/viruses/types.htm
TLDR: Flu has 2 branches, older generation was resistant to the branch Spanish flu came from. Younger generation was weaker to that branch.
